description: From Middle English helle, from Old English hell, from Proto-West Germanic *hallju, from Proto-Germanic *haljō (“concealed place, netherworld”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱel- (“to cover, conceal, save”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian Hälle (“hell”), West Frisian hel (“hell”), Dutch hel (“hell”), German Low German Hell (“hell”), German Hölle (“hell”), Norwegian helvete (“hell”), Icelandic hel (“the abode of the dead, death”). Also related to the Hel of Germanic mythology. See also hele.

entries.meaning: (postpositional) Alternative form of the hell or like hell.
(Australia, impolite, sometimes considered vulgar) Very; used to emphasize strongly.
(countable, hyperbolic, figuratively) A place or situation of great suffering in life.
examples: My new boss is making my job a hell.
I went through hell to get home today.
a convenient little gambling hell for those who had grown reckless
You don’t have a snowball's chance in hell.

entries.meaning: (sometimes considered vulgar) Used as an intensifier in phrases grammatically requiring a noun.
examples: I’m as mad as hell and I’m not going to take it any more.
What the hell is wrong with you?!
He says he’s going home early? Like hell he is.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A place into which a tailor throws shreds, or a printer discards broken type.
In certain games of chase, a place to which those who are caught are carried for detention.
(colloquial, with on) Something extremely painful or harmful (to)
examples: That steep staircase is hell on my knees.

description: From German hellen (“to brighten, burnish”). Related to Dutch hel (“clear, bright”) and German hell (“clear, bright”).

verbs.description: hell (third-person singular simple present hells, present participle helling, simple past and past participle helled)

entries.meaning: (rare, metal-working) To add luster to; to burnish (silver or gold).
examples: To hell gold or gilt workː take two ounces of tartar, two ounces of sulfur.. and it will give it a fine luster.

description: From Old Norse hella (“to pour”). Cognate with Icelandic hella (“to pour”), Norwegian helle (“to pour”), Swedish hälla (“to pour”). See also hield.

verbs.description: hell (third-person singular simple present hells, present participle helling, simple past and past participle helled)

examples: Gosh, the sickle went into me handː Down hell'd the bluid.
